docs.snippet: German Chancellor Angela Merkel told U.S. President Donald Trump that the global fight against terrorism was no excuse for banning refugees or people from Muslim-majority countries from entering the United States, her spokesman said on Sunday....

docs.snippet: SUFFERN, N. Y., June 27 -- Anticipating an influx of transients in connection with the construction of the New York State Thruway, the Suffern board of trustees has adopted a resolution to prohibit the establishment of trailer camps, tourist cabin...
docs.lead_paragraph: SUFFERN, N. Y., June 27 -- Anticipating an influx of transients in connection with the construction of the New York State Thruway, the Suffern board of trustees has adopted a resolution to prohibit the establishment of trailer camps, tourist cabins and tourist camps within the village.
docs.abstract: Suffern, NY, trustees bd bars tourist camps within city limits; fears effect of NYS Thruway

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: Iran said on Saturday it would stop U.S. citizens entering the country in retaliation to Washington's visa ban against Tehran and six other majority-Muslim countries announced by new U.S. President Donald Trump....

headline.main: SOVIET KEEPS BAN ON ENVOYS' TOURS; Shuns U.S. Suggestion That Both Ease Travel Curbs

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Outside the Middle West, its reputation rests largely on the Grand Hotel, a white-frame Victorian splendor, and, with the courage of convictions other places should envy, on its absolute ban of the motor vehicle in favor of the bicycle and horse. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Outside the Middle West, its reputation rests largely on the Grand Hotel, a white-frame Victorian splendor, and, with the courage of convictions other places should envy, on its absolute ban of the motor vehicle in favor of the bicycle and horse. But Mackinac Island, a six-square-mile dot of Michigan in upper Lake Huron, is much more, one of those unusual resorts whose attractions are more than a match for the words of its brochure writers. ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times. It has military and commercial history - the fort overlooking the chief settlement was built to defend the fur business that made John Jacob Astor the country's first millionaire - a sedate way of life that has changed little since Chicago meat barons began making it their playground a century ago and marine beauty almost in the shadow of the Mackinac Bridge, the world's third longest suspension bridge. The island also has, as local residents will tell you, probably the continent's cleanest, most pollen-free air. And where else can you see the sun rise over one Great Lake and set on another, giving the impression that you are hundreds of miles at sea?
